content.content: We disenfranchised so many of our users that day and networks of their friends. To my knowledge… this topic hit a dead end a while back. There are people to this day that still hold a grudge against us over this. I know, user beware, but like… Was there lots of drama? Yes, Did people file legal action? Why did this topic die? Were we salty about that? Do we just not have the bandwidth? IMO, it’s never too late to do right by our users, even if it’s years later. It might not bring everyone back, but at least we show good faith on our part. I think it’s worth revisiting this topic.

content.content: The issue for me at the time is that this was a chain congestion issue not a protocol bug. There was no new information discovered that day. Yes the risk was not well advertised but we are talking about leveraging with defi in 2020. You could organise a goodwill gesture but the risk of creating a bad precedent always felt high to me. You don’t want the protocol to be perceived as  liable for stuff that’s within its official risk window. Otherwise you are asking for unbounded trouble.

content.content: Black Thursday was a mistake and it is acknowledged as such.  There was a promise of fair liquidation that did not occur and it was massively consequential.  The losses were felt far and wide and the protocol itself was hurt badly in needing to cover the surplus buffer gap at supremely low prices. But I believe the subject of compensation should be put to rest.  This subject is always going to be difficult because those who had losses are going to feel the severity of those losses and desire to be made whole.  However, we must also recognize that the losses are great and compensation would come at a cost.  It would come at the expense of growth potential and at the expense of those who came later with no idea about Black Thursday and simply saw a great idea that is lucrative, useful, and efficient if it works properly. Black Thursday was a software mistake.  Those happen to young projects.  Unfortunately it was a costly mistake that hit MKR’s reputation and its own financial security.  But the world moves on and we have to keep up.  We can spend our time stewing over our losses or contribute toward building something better.  In that sense, MKR is stronger and more bulletproof with things like the emergency shutdown module and liquidations 2.0.  Hopefully something like Black Thursday never happens again.  We are sorry that this happened and we know it hurts.  It hurts and it’s not fair.  But this is the world we live in and the cost of being an early adopter.  From what I’ve seen, the community here is actually very compassionate.  I think I remember a SR to make someone whole for their mistake in accidentally burning their money.  But this is just a different type of request and really the only fair scenario would be for the guy who exploited the bug and took all the collateral to give it back.  Unfortunately, that does not seem like it’s going to happen.  Again, very sorry for those who lost large amounts.  At least you were in the crypto world before the massive spike in growth and hopefully your other holdings have done very well and at least you still had a portion of your collateral in the Dai that you borrowed at higher prices.

content.content: I see, I think we mean the same thing. I don’t think direct compensation is the issue. The risk is part of the whole system, and on that basis, Ethereum poor performance could be held responsible for that. But it doesn’t make sense to me. We defended ourselves against irrational claims, we fixed the code, we took all rationally justifiable, reasonable and necessary steps. Indeed, we are unlikely to bring back those lost early adopters, and those who say that any further steps would have very little quantifiable benefit are probably right. But is that really all we can do? The kind of cold professionalism that characterises the current protocol changes is an important and inevitable part of progress and desirable for our future.  As time goes on, the old, sentimental ‘let’s completely rewrite the world’s financial system’ attitude will inevitably have to take a more rational form, but the question is: are we really rewriting the system or are we just copying the way it works? This can be measured, for example, by how we deal with problems, whether we only treat deposits as financial capital, or whether we see the people behind them when its needed. The ability to act with compassion can be an important financial innovation, because the current financial system is totally inadequate for this. You are right that it would be very hard to do it well, and I have no idea how to do it well. But just because something is difficult does not mean it is impossible. One thing is for sure, if we close the issue and stop talking about it, the problem will slowly disappear and some people will be happy about it. For example, those who were “lucky” enough to take advantage of what happened.

content.content: I should have looked over some of the previous posts on this topic before posting. I just generally believe it’s a good look to accept some part of the blame and offer some kind of plan for compensation, even if it’s years later. We won’t reclaim most of the lost customers, but it’s still the right thing to do, imo. That said, looking back at some of the previous posts on this topic, some of my views:  There is no “attacker” to go after, even if we know who they may be. Whoever did the zero bids was playing by the rules. It would have been right of him to return the ETH as a white hat, but by no means was there an obligation to. Lawyers and judges should not be involved in any compensation we ultimately may or may not offer. There is no strong/defensible case for MakerDAO to be liable for the losses borrowers suffered that day. It was/is a nascent technology and user beware. Compensation is purely a goodwill gesture, which admits that our protocol could have functioned better that day.  I’ll leave this here for now, as I know bandwidth is thin. I do believe it would be a good look for our brand and reputation, but I’m not married to pressing this any further.
